gw.pl.persistence.core.effdate.entity

Interface EffDatedBase

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Bean, com.guidewire.commons.entity.BundleProvider, java.lang.Comparable<Bean>, Editable, Extractable, com.guidewire.pl.domain.extract.gen.ExtractableStubI, IGosuObject, com.guidewire.commons.entity.Keyable, KeyableBean, com.guidewire.commons.entity.Sourceable, Versionable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    EffDated, EffDatedBranch

    public interface EffDatedBase
extends Extractable, Editable
    This is the base class for EffDated and EffDatedBranch. These two types of beans make up an effective dated graph, with a single EffDatedBranch at the head and many EffDateds within the graph. These two types have some very important differences, namely that an EffDatedBranch is actually not effective dated, meaning all of its values are the same throughout its effective range (or period range), whereas a single "logical" EffDated can map to several EffDated instances representing different versions at different dates in its effective range. For example, a car with licence plate XYZ represents the "logical" bean. However the car is painted different colors depending on its effective date, at t0 its Red and at t1 its Blue. The Red and Blue versions of the car are referring to the same car with licence plate XYZ but represent different points in time.

    All versions of the same logical bean will share the same FixedId. To operate on all versions of a logical bean you use its EffDatedVersionList. An EffDatedVersionList, or version list, allows you to see all versions of a logical bean and navigate to related beans and version lists.

    An instance of a bean (a version) will typically have a slice date set on it. In most cases we want to view an effective dated graph as of a particular moment in effective time (lets forget model time), e.g. I want to view what I have covered in my policy at t0. T0 is the slice date and you're viewing the effective graph at that date. Typically this slice date is set on the EffDatedBranch. As you navigate from the branch at the head of the graph to beans within the graph this slice date is carried forth, so when you traverse to a particular array element off of the branch that bean (an EffDated) will be "sliced" at t0 as well. You are traversing the graph in "slice" mode.

    The corollary of slice mode is "window" mode. In window mode you aren't viewing the branch or bean at a particular moment in time but across its entire effective range. If a bean isn't slice (its slice date is null) then you can't traverse a link or array on that bean because you won't know which version of the linked bean to return, e.g. the Read car at t0 or the Blue car at t1? For this reason you cannot traverse links when a bean is in window mode, you can only access local fields. To traverse links you either need to slice the bean at a particular date or get the bean's EffDatedVersionList.

    • Field Detail

      • BASEDONID_DYNPROP

        static final DynamicEntityPropertyInfoReference<ILinkPropertyInfo> BASEDONID_DYNPROP

    • Method Detail

      • isPromoted

        boolean isPromoted()
        Check if this bean or branch has been promoted. A promoted bean is also locked and cannot be changed.

        An EffDated is never promoted independent of its related EffDatedBranch, meaning if the branch is promoted every bean in the graph will be promoted, and if the branch is not promoted no bean in the graph can be promoted.

        Returns:
        True if promoted.

      • getSliceDate

        java.util.Date getSliceDate()
        Date which this bean is "sliced" or viewed. If you traverse from this bean to another bean or beans via a link or array, only beans that are effective at this slice date will be returned. The beans that are returned will be sliced at this date as well. If NULL then the bean is in "window" mode.

        In most cases a bean will be sliced, window mode is used in special cases.

        Returns:
        Date which bean is sliced or null if in window mode.

      • isSlice

        boolean isSlice()
        Whether this bean is sliced. If a bean is sliced then you can navigate from this bean to another bean or beans via a link or array, if it's unsliced (in "window" mode) you cannot navigate from this bean.

        In most cases a bean will be sliced, window mode is used in special cases.

        Returns:

      • getVersionList

        EffDatedVersionList getVersionList()
        Get the version list for this bean. An EffDatedVersionList is a representation of a logical bean through its effective range. For example, if a bean has changes at three separate effective dates then the version list will comprise 3 versions of the bean, one for each of these dates.

        You can use an EffDatedVersionList to traverse from this bean to other linked beans in window mode. Recall that in window mode you cannot traverse links directly from the bean.

        Although an EffDatedBranch only has a single version throughout its effective range you can still get its EffDatedVersionList in order to navigate in window mode from the branch to its related EffDateds.

        Returns:
        Version list for this bean

      • getLinkVersionList

        EffDatedVersionList getLinkVersionList(ILinkPropertyInfo link)
        Get the version list for an effective dated foreign key. You need this method because it's the only way to get the version list for a foreign key bean if you're in window mode. You can't call this.getFKBean().getVersionList() since you can't traverse the array and there are no methods on EffDatedVersionList to access a FK (only arrays).

        This bean can be unsliced or sliced when this is called.

        Parameters:
        link - Effective dated foreign key
        Returns:
        Version list for an effective dated foreign key

      • setLinkVersionList

        void setLinkVersionList(ILinkPropertyInfo link,
                      EffDatedKey key)
        Set a foreign key by passing in an EFfDatedKey (effectively the EffDatedVersionList or FixedId of the bean). You need this method because it's the only way to set a foreign key given a FixedId (and no context for when that FixeId might be effective).

        This bean can be unsliced or sliced when this is called.

        Parameters:
        link - Effective dated foreign key to set
        key - EffDatedKey of the bean (effectively the EffDatedVersionList or FixedId of the bean)

      • getSliceUntyped

        EffDatedBase getSliceUntyped(java.util.Date sliceDate)
        Slice this bean at a particular date. This bean can be unsliced or sliced when this method is called. The slice date must be within the effective range of this bean or an exception will be thrown. If you want to get at the version of this "logical" bean at a date outside of this particular bean's effective range then use this.getVersionList().getVersionAsOf(sliceDate).getSliceUntyped(sliceDate).
        Parameters:
        sliceDate - Date at which to slice this bean.
        Returns:
        Sliced version of the bean.

      • getEffDatedKey

        EffDatedKey getEffDatedKey()
        Get an effective date independent key for this bean. This key will include the BranchId and the FixedId. This is the key for the "logical" bean.

        An EffDatedKey only really applies to EffDateds as an EffDatedBranch is the same throughout its effective range (or its period range) so there is no difference between the "logical" bean and the actual bean.
